pros: Supportive team culture, excellent work-life balance, and strong leadership guidance. Resources and training are abundant, helping employees grow technically and professionally. The onboarding program is also well-structured and empowering.
cons: Amazon’s fast-paced environment can be overwhelming at times. Navigating internal tools and processes may require time and patience, especially for newcomers.

pros: Come build your muscle as a software engineer - lots of learn everyday
cons: The pros come at the cost of compromising work-life balance

pros: Cool projects to work on. You can learn a lot
cons: Bad work life balance . Incompetent and micro managing managers

summary: Working with smart people and growth
pros: Working with smart people and good career growth. Would recommend to someone who needs career growth
cons: Too many projects at a time which leads to too many meetings affecting work life balance

pros:
Pays well and pretty solid company that has a lot
Of interesting things going on and
cons: Bad management and a lot of politics that can affect enjoying your jobs

pros: There are great people to work with, great perks, and some interesting problems.
cons: sometimes there’s a lot of red tape due to size

pros: Challenging probs to solve . Access to latest AI models via AWS
cons: Many orga are directionless , L8 leaders in most orga are cluless or have ni strategy , resulting in constant org changes , no stability and no differentiation of talent

pros: The pay is good for the most part. Decent benefits.
cons: You will have no life and you will be miserable

pros: Have worked with some really smart people and had a few great managers
cons: Some organizations reward the wrong type of behavior and turn south very quickly

summary: Customer Facing engineering is more chill
pros:
Flexible work hours and good work life balance
No micro management 
Good variety of work with the customers
cons:
Bad leadership and short-sighted decision making
Benefits and pay is super mid
Career progression in ProServe org is too bureaucratic and painful

pros: In good role with good visibility to continue to grow personally
cons: Growth and think big is non existent now since 2022

pros: External recognition for Faang. Makes you feel good about it.
cons: Overworked. Long hours and not satisfying work. Need your manager’s blessing to grow.

summary: Good company to start your career
pros: - A lot to learn from different people and gain different experiences
cons:
- Role guidelines are subjective and are vaguely followed
- Pay scale for non tech classified roles are not even sustainable and they expect tech skills
- growth is directly proportional to your manager and your leadership. If they feel like then only you will get promoted

summary: Career path dependent on your manager
pros: Great place to learn with a lot of good processes
cons: Your experience and career growth is largely dependent on your manager

pros: Only made for workoholics with no life outside work. They give you opportunity to work on as many projects as you want.
cons: Burn out and Return to Office with badge monitoring. Bad culture

pros: If you are smart and thrive with conflict and politics you can work on a scale unlike any other.
cons: So much politics, horrible talent review process, so big and corporate that you're never going to feel human working there.

summary: Wlb is bad. Good place if you want to slog and grow
pros: Compensation was good, interesting projects and possibility of growth. Team members are good.
cons: Work life balance is a mess. Product and other teams are non existent. Tech does everything so is responsible for everything including the chaos.

summary: Mediocre work life balance, but you can learn a lot
pros: Many talented people to get to know. You will learn not only skills but how to organize your work etc.
cons: Mediocre work life balance and micromanagement (you need to close certain amount of tickets during a sprint)

pros:
- talented people
- decent pay
- looks good on resume
cons: It’s Amazon… there’s already enough negative reviews out there. Just read one of those because they are mostly true.

summary: Interesting work, smart people, have to navigate politics as expected in a large org
pros: Scale of work is great, lots of learning, easy to move internally
cons: Many stakeholders, bias for action valued over strategy, lots of churn

pros: You learn a lot. Many SDEs are good, lots of scope to change teams during your initial years.
cons:
You have to fight to again visibility, no matter how talented your are you need to kiss management’s a..

Lot of internal re-orgs and internal teams trying to cannibalize your service is common. 

Manger will leave left and right you need to fight for your promo.

pros: A lot of internal tools and computing resources. There are some smart folks and the products are well known
cons: A lot of politics and micromanagement, many reshuffle and many small reorg

summary: Avoid it at all costs unless you’re desperate
pros:
Don’t join unless you’re desperate. 
The only thing that may benefit you is the “big”name stamp on your resume.
cons:
Tenure-based instead of merit-based promotions. 
Reorgs every month every quarter every year. 
No vision from leadership. 
5-day RTO. 
Backstabbing peer reviews.

summary: Good for a sprint, not suitable for marathons.
pros:
1. A high-paced environment, provides quick learning opportunities.
2. Decent overall compensation.
3. Jack of all trades, master of none or maybe one.
cons:
1. Little respect for boundaries.
2. All work and no play makes Jack a dull boy.
3. Exhaustive enough to prevent you from preparing for a switch.
4. Incapable and opaque managers - L7-L8.
5. Compensation/amount of work done very poor.
6. No extra benefits than compensation whatsoever.

summary: Amazing if you have a great team and manager
pros: Lots of room to grow and learn. Many exciting projects.
cons: Constant re-orgs and politics make it difficult to actually make an impact.

pros: Smart colleagues and management. Good problems to solve. Growth opportunities
cons: Complicated tech slows down development and release of new features

pros:
Pay is there and you get AMZN stock
You can get to work on some cool projects at AWS
Literally anyone will riff with you about this bs 
Healthcare and insurance is adequate for cost
You can get an org with a lot of smart people
cons:
RTO5
Benefits seem to be disappearing 
Pay is diminishing based on bs
Oncall will give you PTSD like Vietnam 
You can get stuck working on initiatives that no one thought about giving you brain cancer in the process
Attrition and brain drain is real
PIP exists although I have never personally seen it, it feels like existential dread
Documentation hell exists
Management hell exists

summary: Not the best WLB, but a good place to learn
pros:
- Great exposure to big scale problems
- Great opportunities to learn esp as a new grad
cons:
- No dedicated new grad program
- Practically non existent benefits or perks

pros:
Be an expert AWS master with actual usages.
Learn that you are filled with people dummer than you.
cons:
Horrible documentation 
Horrible code quality requirement


Overall the shop is filled with automated systems that have no understanding what needs to be done.

Be ready to work with having no ownership in pride in making stuff.

Slowest process in doing things.  Waterfall development pretending as Agile continuous development.

summary: Not what it used to be
pros: Cool projects, to work on with awesome team mates but limited growth
cons: Culture stinks and limited growth opportunities do two years and bounce
